stem: The flight nurse is transporting a patient with an intrarenal acute kidney injury. A finding consistent with this diagnosis is
rationale: A urine osmolality of 1500 mOsm/kg is elevated outside the normal range and is indicative of volume excess and intrarenal acute kidney injury (AKI). In intrarenal AKI, this would lead to volume overload, dry mucous membranes are seen with volume deficit. Intrarenal kidney injury would lead to decreased urine output. A blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 15 mg/dL is a normal value. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 625

stem: A patient who is 34 weeks pregnant was diagnosed with preeclampsia after presenting with proteinuria and a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg. She was treated with labetalol (Trandate) and a magnesium sulfate infusion before transport. During the transfer, vital signs were recorded as follows: HR 95 beats/min BP 150/100 mmHg RR 24 breaths/min O2 saturation 94% (room air) Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score 15 Which of the following interventions is indicated?
options: C) Increase magnesium sulfate infusion rate
rationale: Although this preeclamptic patient's blood pressure is elevated, it is not above the treatment threshold of systolic blood pressure ≥160 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure ≥110 mmHg. A therapeutic intervention for patients with preeclampsia receiving magnesium is to administer oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 95%. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 284; Advanced Critical Care for the Transport Professional, 1st Ed. (2024), p. 162-163.

stem: A patient with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) is being transported via fixed-wing aircraft. After ascent, it is essential for the transport nurse to
options: D) check for a hematoma at the arterial site
rationale: Rezeroing the arterial line is essential. Checking for a hematoma at the insertion site and reassessing distal pulses are components of the ongoing assessment of a balloon pump. They are not specific to altitude changes. These should be assessed at regular intervals and after the patient is moved. For example, after loading and unloading. Adjusting the timing is not affected by altitude. Timing would only be adjusted if there was an issue. Pressure measure lines will be affected by changes in barometric pressure and should always be rezeroed after ascent and descent or after pressurization and depressurization of an aircraft. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 314-318; 327

stem: A child is being transferred due to a head injury following an impact with a car. During the transport, the child becomes anxious and tachycardic. The nurse should anticipate this is due to
options: C) use of anxiety of the child
rationale: The nurse should anticipate other sources of bleeding. Hypotension is rarely seen in isolated head injuries. When hypotension is seen in multi-system trauma patient, hypotension/hemorrhage should always be ruled out and treated. Hypotension is most often a result of secondary acute hemorrhage from: impaired autonomic nervous system control, iatrogenically from medication use, or less commonly from spinal cord injury or acute diabetes insipidus. If euvolemia does not correct hypotension, infusions of norepinephrine or phenylephrine should be initiated to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure and cerebral perfusion pressure. Anxiousness and tachycardia are natural responses of a child in this situation. However, the critical nurse should have a deeper understanding and suspicion of hypovolemia related to secondary acute hemorrhage. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 240

stem: The flight team is called to transport an intubated child who was found in a house fire. The child has suffered significant burns to their chest, back, bilateral arms, neck, and face. The child has been difficult to ventilate with limited chest wall movement. Ventilator settings: Pressure Control Ventilation FiO2: 100% PEEP: 5 cm H2O Pressure control: 10 cm H2O Respirations: 20 breaths/min Peak inspiratory pressure: 45 cm H2O Vitals signs: BP 95/55 mmHg HR 125 beats/min RR 20 breaths/min O2 Sat: 85% (ventilated) The MOST appropriate intervention is:
options: C) Escharotomy of the chest wall
rationale: Circumferential burns to the chest wall can cause eschar tissue that will impede chest wall movement. Escharotomy will allow for movement of the chest wall and will improve ventilation. Increasing PEEP with increasing peak inspiratory pressures. Suctioning the airway may improve ventilation, but is not a definitive fix for poor chest movement. Performing a needle decompression will not improve chest wall movement. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 282

stem: The flight nurse responds to a patient who sustained first-degree frostbite to their feet. The patient's feet are hyperemic and swollen. The sending facility has started rewarming the patient's feet, which will be continued in transport with passive rewarming. Which assessment findings would the flight nurse expect the patient to develop as passive rewarming continues?
options: A) Numbness with pale and edema
B) Decreased pain and redness with increased edema
D) Increased pain and cyanosis, mottled skin
rationale: As the rewarming of areas of first-degree frostbite, the tissue becomes mottled, cyanotic and painful due to superficial thawing of tissues. During the rewarming of first-degree frostbite, skin becomes deep red, hot and dry to touch. First-degree frostbite does not develop blisters. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 408

stem: The flight nurse has had a dental procedure to fill a cavity. The nurse should wait how long before returning to work?
rationale: The dental pulp of a tooth can cause severe dental pain called barotrauma. Waiting 48-72 hours after invasive procedures will allow enough time for the tooth to equalize or prevent pain. The other options are either too much or too little time. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 34

stem: The flight nurse is transporting a patient with thoracic trauma. The nurse should recognize that a late sign of hypoxia in this patient is
rationale: Cyanosis is a late finding of hypoxia due to thoracic trauma, and its absence is not a reliable indicator of adequate oxygenation. Low SaO2 is the defining characteristic of hypoxia. Rapid respiratory rate and accessory muscle use are early signs of hypoxia. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2013), p. 504

stem: Three air ambulances have been called to the scene of a motor vehicle collision involving a tour bus and a tanker carrying diesel fuel. First responders have activated the Incident Command System (ICS). Once on scene, the flight teams can anticipate that they will MOST likely be assigned to which ICS section?
rationale: In large-scale incidents, transport teams generally will be assigned to the Operations section. Logistics supports the Operations group by providing additional resources such as equipment, personnel, and more. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 303

stem: A patient receiving mechanical ventilation is noted to have an increased respiratory rate after engine start. The flight nurse recognizes the PRIORITY intervention is to administer
rationale: When the engine starts up, the patient experiences vibration, a normal flight stressor. The patient might require more sedation with the increased sensory input. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 67

stem: The nurse arrives on scene after request of an ambulance. The patient is laying on the stretcher and there are no obvious signs of trauma. The EMS provider states the patient has shortness of breath, hemoptysis and the following vital signs: BP: 130/87 mmHg HR: 126 beats/min RR: 35 breaths/min SpO2: 88% on 4L nasal cannula The nurse suspects the patient has:
rationale: This patient is likely suffering from a pulmonary embolism. The classic vital signs include tachycardia, hypoxia, and tachypnea. There are no obvious signs of trauma and a hemothorax without trauma and pneumothorax without trauma is unlikely to be a hemothorax without trauma. Pulmonary hypertension is unlikely based on the presentation. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 337

stem: A patient who was struck by a motor vehicle and sustained bilateral femur fractures is receiving mechanical ventilation. The high-pressure alarms sound and the patient appears restless. Ventilator settings and vital signs are as follows: Mode: volume assist control Rate 16 breaths/min Tidal volume: 560 mL PEEP: 5 cm H2O FiO2: 100% BP 177/121 cm Hg HR 114 beats/min RR 26 breaths/min The transport nurse should recognize that the BEST option to improve ventilator compliance and vital signs is to:
options: B) Change the mode of ventilation
rationale: Administering fentanyl (Sublimaze) would be appropriate for this patient as the patient demonstrates all the classic physiological signs of pain, such as hypertension, tachycardia, restlessness and tachypnea. Adequate sedation and analgesia are paramount for any mechanically ventilated patient. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 190

stem: The flight crew is requested to complete a patient transport. The nurse recognizes that the two most common factors in fatal helicopter emergency medical accidents are:
options: A) Mechanical failure and inadequate training
B) Inadequate fuel and their usage
C) Failure to notify other fatigue
D) Pilot error and nighttime operations
rationale: A study by the National Transportation Safety Board revealed that the most frequent factors in HEMS accidents were also pilot error and nighttime operations. This has been validated by subsequent studies. While the other factors are likely contributors, they have not been verified as the most common factors. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 125

stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a patient who has received alteplase (Alteplase) for an occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery. Upon making contact with the patient, the flight nurse recognizes the patient is unresponsive with unequal pupils, which is a change from their baseline stroke assessment. After the airway is managed, the NEXT priority intervention is:
options: B) Sedate the patient with ketamine
C) Immobilize the head and prepare for transport
rationale: An unresponsive patient with unequal pupils should alert the flight nurse to the potential of new intracranial hemorrhage post Alteplase administration. The patient should have a repeat head CT to assess for hemorrhage, as well as shift. Sedating the patient with ketamine could cause an inaccurate neuro exam. Repeat blood glucose may be necessary but is not a priority intervention over CT. Immobilizing the head and preparing for transport are not appropriate interventions for an unresponsive patient. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 292

stem: The nurse is flying in a helicopter when they enter clouds unexpectedly. The pilot asks the nurse to tune the radio to the emergency frequency. The nurse should tune the radio to:
rationale: The universal emergency frequency is 121.5 MHz. The emergency location transmitter (ELT) operates on 406 MHz. The squawk code for emergency is 7700, however this is not a speaking frequency. 243 MHz is no longer utilized as an emergency frequency. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 116

stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient with a femur fracture via interfacility transfer. The flight nurse has received report from the nurse that the patient was treated with two doses of IV narcotics and one dose IV benzodiazepines, which are documented appropriately on the MAR. The patient is alert and oriented, reporting pain at 10 out 10 and is adamant that no pain medications have been administered. The flight nurse should treat the assessed pain level and:
options: A) Assess the patient for a history of substance abuse
B) Confirm to the nurse that long bone fractures are painful and distracting which contributed to missing the administration
C) Confront the nurse for ineffective pain control
D) Report the flight crew's concerns of possible diversion to the hospital supervisor
rationale: Per the Joint Commission, 'Appropriate response for staff can be summarized as "see something, say something." At the institutional level, appropriate responses include: establishing a just culture in which reporting drug diversion is encouraged, assessing harm to patients, consulting with public health officials when tampering with injectable medication is suspected, and prompt reporting to enforcement agencies.' Reference: https://www.jointcommission.org/-/media/tjc/newsletters/quick_safety_drug_diversion_-final2.pdf

stem: A patient has sustained significant facial trauma from impact with the steering wheel during a collision. Assessment at the scene reveals significant soft-tissue swelling, periorbital, and facial asymmetry with malocclusion. On gentle palpation, the patient's face is mobile and there is increased bleeding from the lacerations. Based on these findings, the nurse suspects:
rationale: The nurse should suspect a Le Fort III craniofacial disjunction. Complete separation of the cranial attachments from the facial bones which causes the face to be free floating when assessed. Le Fort III: pyramidal fracture involving the mid face. It involves a triangular segment of the mid-portion of the face and nasal bones. It does not cause free floating of the face. Mandible fracture is a fracture of the jaw bone. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It does not cause free floating of the face. Maxilla fracture is a fracture of the upper jaw bones, as well as part of the nasal bone and eye socket. It is very similar to a Le Fort II fracture. However, a Le Fort III is bilateral whereas a maxilla fracture is unilateral. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 561-562

stem: The transport team is called to an outlying hospital for transport of a patient that is 31 weeks pregnant. The sending RN reports the patient is G3P2 and experienced a 'gush' of fluids 24 hours prior to arriving at the hospital. The vitals are as follows: BP: 126/82 mmHg HR: 105 beats/min RR: 20 breaths/min SPO2: 95% (room air) The nurse knows the PRIORITY intervention is:
options: C) Rapid transport to a maternal center
rationale: The patient has had a PROM (Premature Rupture of Membranes) and the fetus is at risk for neonatal sepsis. There is no need at this point for magnesium. Sterile vaginal exam is contraindicated in the presence of PROM. While rapid transport is indicated, antibiotics should not be delayed. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 463

stem: A patient in a motor vehicle crash has a seatbelt bruise across their upper abdomen. The patient has hypotension and tachycardia after receiving 2L of crystalloid IV fluid. Which of the following should the transport nurse administer FIRST?
rationale: The transport nurse should first administer packed red blood cells. Restoring intravascular volume by carrying capacity is the highest priority. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 134

stem: Multiple flight crew members have expressed concerns over the care abilities of a specific flight nurse and have requested removal from clinical duties. Due to staffing issues, the medical director and leadership elect to allow the flight nurse to continue to staff the clinical crew. If a patient were to receive an injury while under the care of the flight nurse, the air medical provider could be in breach of which of the following professional issues?
rationale: Vicarious liability is an employer's obligation to ensure an employee performs duties safely and competently. Product liability involves the safe use of a manufactured product, collective liability involves when multiple manufacturers collaborate in the production of a faulty product, and alternative liability involves when manufacturers have faulty production in two separate phases of production. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 75

stem: The flight nurse arrives at the scene of a motor vehicle accident. The patient that should be treated FIRST is a:
options: A) 32-year-old with an obvious deformity to the knee and lower leg
B) 21-year-old with a chest wound who is breathing at 5 breaths/min
C) 1-year-old who has an open head injury and is not breathing
D) 54-year-old who is walking towards the nurse complaining of shortness of breath
rationale: The 21-year-old has decreased respirations, making them the priority patient. The 32-year-old with the injured leg would be the second priority. The 1-year-old would be triaged as 'black', last priority, as the patient is unlikely to survive. The 54-year-old would be triaged as 'green' because they are a walking wounded. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 227

stem: The flight team is transporting an adult patient who presents with altered mental status, diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting after working in the yard all day. The patient has a patent airway and stable vital signs. An electrocardiogram shows a wide complex rhythm. What is the PRIORITY intervention for this patient?
rationale: This patient is hyperkalemic secondary to acute renal failure. While administering a fluid bolus may benefit this patient, calcium chloride administration will provide the most benefit. Calcium stabilizes the resting membrane potential, thereby stabilizing cardiac tissue and preventing fatal dysrhythmias. Cooling measures may be indicated for elevated body temperature, but will not treat hyperkalemia. Amiodarone will not provide any benefit for a wide complex rhythm resulting from hyperkalemia. There is no indication that the patient requires hypertonic fluid administration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Medical Critical Care (2026), p. 20-24.

stem: While enroute back to base, the pilot declares an in-flight emergency. The flight nurse's PRIORITY action is:
options: A) Contact air traffic control and declare an emergency
D) Relayed information about the emergency to relay to dispatch
rationale: The primary role of the transport team during an in-flight emergency is to serve as a resource to the pilot. The first action is to maintain a sterile cockpit so the pilot may aviate, navigate and finally communicate with the med crew. Once the aircraft is under control, the flight team may request a land zone contact dispatch, set the transponder or make emergency radio calls per individual program's policies. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 8th Ed. (2024), p. 98

stem: The flight team was dispatched for a patient who suffered a hard tackle while playing football. On assessment the nurse notes the patient is unable to move their arms or legs and their skin is flushed and warm. Vital signs are: Heart rate: 53 beats/min Blood pressure: 80/47 mmHg Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/min SpO2: 94% (room air) Which type of shock is the patient most likely experiencing?
rationale: Neurogenic shock causes the loss of sympathetic tone from a high thoracic or cervical spinal cord injury. This results in vasodilation (pooling of blood in the venous system), decreased systemic vascular resistance, and decreased blood pressure without compensatory tachycardia. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 8th ed. (2018), p. 4/11

stem: The flight nurse arrives at the scene of a patient who was found after falling the day before. EMS has applied a splint to the obvious left femur fracture. The patient reports that his pain is worse after the splint and his toes are now pale. The nurse's NEXT action should be to:
rationale: The patient may have compartment syndrome. The 5 P's of compartment syndrome are pain out of proportion to the injury, paresthesia, pulselessness, paralysis, and pallor. If caused by a splint or device, it should be loosened. Pain medication can be given after the splint is loosened. If not treated, compartment syndrome could result in the loss of the limb. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 482.

stem: The flight nurse responds to an outlying facility to transport a patient with a femur fracture to a larger hospital. The patient is alert and oriented and states they do not want to go due to uncertainty about the cost of transport. The sending nurse insists they must go by helicopter since the physician ordered the transport. The flight nurse should:
options: A) Assure them insurance will cover the transport
B) Take the patient by ground
C) Refuse to transport the patient
D) Initiate an order for sedation
rationale: A patient with decision-making capacity can always refuse transport. The nurse should explain the risks and benefits of refusing transport and obtain a refusal form if the patient wishes to decline. Another option is to contact the patient advocate at your flight program, if available, to provide information on costs and billing so the patient can make an informed decision about their care. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 335.

stem: The flight nurse is called to the scene of a scuba diving incident where CPR is in progress. A fellow scuba diver reports the patient rapidly ascended to the surface from where he was briefly alert before going into cardiac arrest. The flight nurse suspects the arrest was likely caused by
rationale: During rapid ascent from depth, expanding gas may form a bubble that travels to the brain causing paralysis, focal seizures, disorientation and unconsciousness. The definitive treatment is a hyperbaric chamber. CPR should be performed along with other interventions including ACLS procedures. The nurse should also inform the pilot to fly at the lowest safe altitude to avoid aggravating the result. Reference: https://dan.org/health-medicine/health-resource/diseases-conditions/decompression-illness-what-is-it-and-what-is-the-treatment/

stem: The nurse is monitoring a patient who was recently intubated in-flight for respiratory failure. After descending to the landing pad, the nurse notices the Exhaled Tidal Volume decreased from 450ml to 100ml. The nurse's NEXT action should be to
options: A) disconnect the patient from the ventilator and use the bag-mask device
C) check the ETT cuff pressure
D) take a laryngoscope to check ETT placement
rationale: With a descent in altitude, air filled spaces such as the ETT balloon might change in volume. If the cuff is no longer the proper size, a large leak can occur causing decreased exhaled tidal volumes. This is explained by Boyle's law. The ventilator is giving you valuable feedback, using the BMV is not the correct first troubleshooting step. The same is true for reseating the ventilation. While placement might be the cause, the cuff pressure is the more likely culprit. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2024), p. 52

stem: A patient at a remote construction site has sustained a severe laceration from a broken window. Coworkers have applied direct pressure and an appropriately positioned tourniquet. Despite these measures, active bleeding continues at the wound and the patient appears pale, cool, and clammy. What is the NEXT appropriate action?
options: C) Loosen the first tourniquet and move it more proximally
D) Secure large bore IV access
rationale: This patient is in hemorrhagic shock. Controlling bleeding is the immediate life-saving measure. Additional tourniquets can be applied to the extremity until the bleeding stops. Reference: https://www.naemt.org/docs/default-source/education-documents/tccc/bleeding_control_lesson_01_handout.pdf?sfvrsn=2, p. 9.

stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a patient diagnosed with an open book pelvic fracture. The patient has received multiple blood products and vital signs are stable upon arrival. Upon loading the patient into the helicopter, the nurse notes a significant decrease in blood pressure. The MOST likely cause is:
options: A) Dislodging of tamponade in the retroperitoneal space
B) Acute pain related to movement
D) Iatrogenic hematoma related to movement
rationale: Retroperitoneal injuries can form hematomas that can eventually tamponade with adequate resuscitation. The movement of a patient can dislodge these hematomas and massive hemorrhage will occur. The acute change in vital signs related to movement in a patient with open book pelvic injury should prompt the flight nurse to suspect bleeding and additional resuscitation should occur. Acute pain would likely cause an increase in blood pressure. Vasovagal response would likely be related to the massive blood loss. Inadequate pain management will likely lead to an increase in blood pressure. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 611

stem: During a high-altitude environment, a transport nurse notes a decrease in the patient's oxygen saturation. Which of the following gas laws is most likely responsible?
rationale: Dalton's Law is most likely responsible. Dalton's Law refers to the partial pressure of oxygen. At altitude increases, the partial pressure decreases meaning less oxygen is available. Graham's Law refers to the principle that lower molecular weight molecules diffuse at a faster rate than higher molecular weight molecules. This law does not have a direct impact on patients' care or equipment management in the air medical environment. Charles' Law refers to changes in volume as it relates to temperature. Higher temperatures will cause gases to expand. Boyle's Law refers to the change in volume as it relates to altitude. Higher altitudes will cause gas to expand. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 26

stem: The flight team is transporting a patient who is mechanically ventilated. The patient is on assist control ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min and a tidal volume of 350 mL. The patient is breathing spontaneously. This patient is MOST at risk for:
rationale: A patient who is breathing spontaneously on assist control is able to trigger a breath prior to the ventilator delivering a set breath above the volume set on the ventilator. If the patient hasn't fully exhaled the previous breath, they are at risk for breath stacking. This can lead to increased peak airway pressures and decreased ventilation. Hyperventilation is a long-term concern associated with breath stacking if the breath stacking is not addressed. Atelectasis is not a complication of breath stacking. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6621156/

stem: The flight team was called to the scene of a music festival to transport a patient who was assaulted. The patient was found with an altered level of consciousness, palpable skull deformities, and a single stab wound to the right upper back. The flight team performed drug-assisted intubation and covered the stab wound with a three-sided dressing. Vital signs are stable. During transport, the patient suddenly develops an elevated Peak Inspiratory Pressure of 45 cm H2O. Current vital signs: BP 72/46 mmHg HR 130 beats/min RR 16 breaths/min SpO2: 79% (100% FiO2) ETCO2: 26 mmHg Glasgow Coma Scale 3 The PRIORITY intervention is to:
options: A) perform re-intubation of the airway
rationale: Patients with penetrating trauma to the torso are at risk for open pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can convert a pneumothorax into a tension pneumothorax. This patient's suddenly increased Peak Inspiratory Pressure, tachycardia, hypotension, and hypoxia suggest possible tension pneumothorax. Removing the three-sided dressing and performing needle decompression will temporarily relieve the tension pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy is the definitive treatment, followed by applying an occlusive dressing to the wound. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 9th ed. (2024), p. 154-152.

stem: The flight nurse responds to a scene call for a patient who is unconscious and has life threatening injuries. Consent for treatment of this patient is:
rationale: Implied consent is operational in emergency situations. Most consent states allow for treatment of life-threatening emergencies if the patient is unable to consent because it is the reasonable thing to do. The other terms do not apply. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 5/75

stem: The 7 Ps of rapid sequence induction include which of the following?
rationale: The 7Ps of RSI are: preparation, preoxygenation, pretreatment, paralysis, protection and positioning, placement with proof and postintubation management. The other choices are not applicable. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 8

stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a patient diagnosed with intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient initially presents with a Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) of 15 and stable vital signs. During flight, the patient's GCS decreases to 10 and the team determines the patient needs an advanced airway. The flight nurse knows what about preparing for advanced airway management in the patient with intracranial hemorrhage?
options: A) Oral airway adjuncts are contraindicated
B) Cervical spine immobilization is only required if injury is present
C) Smaller doses of induction medications are indicated
rationale: BLS airways in this patient population may lead to coughing and gagging which can increase intracranial pressures. They should be avoided until the patient is adequately sedated. Paralytics should not be confused with sedation. Smaller doses of medications are not indicated. Cervical spine immobilization should be maintained in this patient population regardless of injury, until definitive spine movement has been ruled out. Reference: Trauma Nursing: from Resuscitation through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 3/12

stem: The flight team is called to a scene for an adult with multiple gunshot wounds to the chest and abdomen. The patient is intubated. The transport nurse notes an absence of breath sounds in the left lung fields. The chest tube to the right chest has a positive air leak and is functioning without issue, however, there is no drainage or air leak present in the left chest tube system. The ED resident urged the patient is transported now and let the accepting trauma team address this upon arrival. The flight nurse should:
options: B) Request to speak to the attending physician
C) Prepare equipment for needle decompression
rationale: The patient with a non-functioning chest tube needs this resolved prior to departure and ascending to altitude; further blood accumulation in the chest can potentiate hemodynamic collapse. While the ED resident might be responsible for the patient, there is a chain of command within the ED and getting an attending physician involved, in this instance, should help in getting another set of hands to assist. If the attending physician declined, calling the Trauma Center's accepting MD may be warranted, and/or medical directors. Transporting this patient without a functioning chest tube, on a long duration transport, could exacerbate the situation further. Boyle's law should be considered. A needle decompression will only help remove the air, not the blood accumulating in the chest. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p.27; 130-134

stem: A patient with an unstable pelvis was found 6 hours after falling down a ravine and is being evacuated from the scene via helicopter. They were placed on oxygen at 6 L/min via nasal cannula and have the following vital signs: BP 80/45 mm Hg HR 98 beats/min RR 32 breaths/min O2 Sat 100% ETCO2 22 mm Hg The flight nurse recognizes this patient is MOST likely suffering from:
rationale: The low ETCO2 value coupled with vital signs consistent with shock are indicative of a patient in anaerobic metabolism. Neurogenic shock is incorrect because in neurogenic shock bradycardia would be expected. Permissive hypotension is incorrect because there is no indication of an intentional choice to not resuscitate the patient. Pulmonary contusion is incorrect because with a pulmonary contusion it is unlikely the oxygen saturation would be 100% on 6 L. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 198-203

stem: A 34-week pregnant patient arrived at a community emergency room with a severe headache. She was found to have proteinuria, acute kidney injury, and no signs of active labor. Her blood pressure was monitored and she was initiated on a magnesium sulfate infusion. The flight nurse understands that the purpose of the magnesium sulfate infusion is to:
rationale: This patient is showing signs and symptoms of preeclampsia, which increases her risk of seizures. Although magnesium can be used as a tocolytic to prevent preterm labor, in this case, it is being used to prevent seizures because it raises the seizure threshold. Reference: Advanced Critical Care for the Transport Professional, 1st Ed. (2024), p. 162.

stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a 3-year-old child who became unresponsive after playing with an older sibling. According to the mother, a barking sound was heard from the room where the child was playing with small building blocks, and she suspects the child may have swallowed one. Upon arrival, a ground crew is manually ventilating the child. While preparing for rapid sequence induction, the flight crew should have which item available?
rationale: The flight nurse should suspect foreign body aspiration in this child. Magill forceps should be available during the RSI procedure to remove the foreign object once it is visualized, before placing the endotracheal tube. A supraglottic airway may not be used until the foreign body has been removed to avoid further migration into the airway. Humidified oxygen and succinic oxygenation are used to treat croup, but are not appropriate in this situation as the foreign body takes priority. Reference: Wong's Nursing Care of Infants and Children, 12th Ed. (2024), p. 685

stem: A flight crew member who recently had a dental filling placed suffers severe dental pain to the tooth during the ascent phase of flight. This condition is the result of which gas law?
rationale: Boyle's law states that the volume of gas is inversely related to atmospheric pressure. As altitude increases, air expands and small portions of air grow larger. In crew members, this may occur following recent dental surgery. Graham's Law states that the diffusion rate of a gas is inversely proportional to the square root of the mass of its particles. Charles's Law states that gases expand when temperature increases. Gay-Lussac's Law states that pressure of a given mass is directly related to the absolute temperature. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 27

stem: Following an explosion at a manufacturing plant, first responders are preparing a landing zone for the inbound transport team. The landing zone should be located:
options: A) Upwind and uphill from the scene
B) Downwind and downhill from the scene
C) Adjacent to the triage nodes
D) Close to the manufacturing plant
rationale: Being upwind prevents the wind from bringing chemicals towards the team; being uphill is necessary because some chemicals accumulate in low-lying areas. Being upwind and uphill prevents rotor wash from spreading chemicals around the area. The landing zone will need to be away from patient care areas to prevent rotor wash from spreading chemicals. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 47

stem: The flight crew responds to the bedside of a patient with a glioblastoma. The nurse recognizes that the patient's increased intracranial pressure is a result of:
rationale: The Monroe-Kellie doctrine states that cranial vault is composed of brain, blood, and CSF. When a condition changes volume in one area it decreases the others and results in an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP). Boyle's law describes the relationship of volume and pressure when temperature is constant. Cushing's syndrome describes the physiologic effects of increased ICP. Cerebral autoregulation is the mechanism by which the brain maintains perfusion by varying pressure. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 287

stem: The transport team is transporting a 2-year-old child who has a suspected bacterial infection. The child is responsive to painful stimuli, and has mottled skin. The patient's vital signs are as follows: BP 60/30 mm Hg HR 180 beats/min RR 10 breaths/min T 94.1°F (34.5°C) Which of the following interventions would be the highest priority
options: B) Administer broad spectrum of antibiotics
C) Initiate a normal saline bolus of 20 mL/kg
rationale: Initiating a normal saline bolus of 20 mL/kg is correct because this patient is in uncompensated septic shock. Restoring an adequate circulating volume is the highest priority. Administering adenosine and performing synchronized cardioversion is incorrect because the heart rate is due to profound shock, not SVT. Administering a broad spectrum of antibiotics is incorrect because resuscitation to correct the fluid deficit comes before antibiotic administration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 551

stem: The nurse lands on scene of a farm accident. The patient has suffered an amputation of the left arm. The bleeding is controlled and the vitals are stable. When preparing the extremity for transport, it should be:
options: A) Wrapped in dry gauze, in a plastic bag, on dry ice
B) Wrapped in a saline-filled plastic bag, on ice
C) Wrapped in saline-soaked gauze, in a plastic bag, on ice
D) Wrapped in dry gauze, on saline-soaked gauze, placed below
rationale: It is recommended to wrap the extremity in wet gauze or a clean sheet, then place in a bag on ice. It is not recommended to use dry ice. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 265

stem: The dispatchers have not been able to contact the transport vehicle for greater than 20 minutes, and the crew has not arrived at the destination. The dispatcher should activate the
rationale: A post accident incident plan is a program policy that outlines the responsibilities of the communications specialist and program administration of a transport program during and immediately after an accident or incident. A disaster plan is developed for a group of people at a facility that details what needs to be done, how, when, and by whom before and after the time an anticipated disastrous event is expected to occur. There is no such thing as an unscheduled event plan. Incident command plan is a management concept designed to clarify command relationships from different responding agencies during a disaster or mass casualty event requiring a multi-jurisdictional response. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 85, 112

stem: The flight crew is called to transport a 6-year-old child following a submersion injury. The child is awake, alert, and breathing spontaneously but was reported to have been underwater for 2 minutes and required CPR when EMS arrived. Which intervention should the flight nurse perform before transport?
options: D) Administer 20 mL/kg of isotonic fluid bolus
rationale: Although the child's respiratory condition requires close monitoring over the next few days, their alertness and wakefulness are reassuring signs despite the drowning incident. A cervical collar should be placed in case a fall or diving injury caused the drowning incident. If vital signs are stable, a fluid bolus can be withheld unless the patient shows signs of decompensation. Reference: Nelson's Essentials of Pediatrics, 6th ed., p. 1044.

stem: For informed consent, in addition to explaining the risks and benefits to the patient, the transport nurse should also include
options: A) other possible alternative treatments available
B) signs and symptoms leading to the need for the procedure
D) the length of time of the procedure
rationale: Informed consent includes all of the following essential components: description of procedure to be performed; available alternatives to procedure; risks and benefits of procedure and alternatives; patient understanding of procedure, alternatives, and associated risks/benefits of all; practitioner or physician presence during consent administration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 124-125

stem: While preparing for transfer, the flight nurse fails to properly secure the patient to the transport sled. During a hard landing, the patient sustains injuries. The nurse could be found guilty of:
rationale: Malpractice is committed when all of the required elements are present: presence of duty, breach of duty, foreseeability, causation, injury and damages. Foreseeability and causation are elements that must be present for malpractice to occur, but are not the actual violation. Malfeasance is a type of breach of duty caused by an act of commission. The question describes nonfeasance, or an act of omission. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 5/74

stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient with a diagnosis of MI to a specialty resource hospital. When comparing the patient's presenting ECG to the flight crew's ECG, the crew interprets the presence of Q-waves greater than 1 mm wide with a deflection half the height and depth of the entire complex. The flight crew recognizes the ECG changes as
rationale: Presence of a Q-wave has been associated with transmural AMI; however, studies now demonstrate that both Q-wave (STEMI) and non-Q-wave (non-STEMI) infarcts can be transmural or subendocardial. In general, Q-wave infarctions are associated with a larger region of myocardial necrosis, higher enzyme levels, fresh coronary thrombosis, frequent vomiting, congestive HF, conduction defects, dysrhythmias, and loss collateral circulation. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 241

stem: A tree trimmer, who was electrocuted after making contact with an overhead power line, has full-thickness burns on the right hand and foot and a painful, tight right forearm. During transport, the patient is screaming and writhing in pain despite several doses of analgesics. The cardiac monitor shows sinus rhythm with frequent multifocal PVCs. The flight nurse PRIORITIZES which intervention:
options: B) Elevate right arm to the level of the heart
C) Apply a cold compress to the right arm
D) Emergent escharotomy of the right forearm
rationale: Electrical burns pose a risk of compartment syndrome. This patient reports extreme pain, even though their contact burns are full-thickness and treatable. The abnormal appearance of their forearm needs careful monitoring. The arm should be elevated to heart level to enhance blood flow. While electrical burns also carry a risk of cardiac instability and arrhythmias, the PVCs currently do not require intervention. If conservative management does not improve the condition of the right arm, a fasciotomy should be considered as the next step. An escharotomy is only necessary in cases of full-thickness circumferential burns. Applying a cold compress is contraindicated for this injury. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 620.

stem: The flight nurse responds to a patient from Florida who arrived at a mountain resort area two days prior. The patient complains of severe headache, fatigue and dyspnea at rest. Vital signs are: HR 115 beats/min RR 28 breaths/min with dry cough BP 142/88 mmHg SpO2 68% (2L nasal cannula) What disorder is this patient likely suffering from and what (apart from oxygen administration) is the most beneficial treatment for this patient?
options: A) HACE (High Altitude Cerebral Edema), Descent
B) HAPE (High Altitude Pulmonary Edema), Descent
C) HAPE (High Altitude Pulmonary Edema), Labs
D) HACE (High Altitude Cerebral Edema), Mannitol
rationale: HAPS can occur at altitudes between 8000-10000 feet and is usually associated with rate of ascent to altitude and typically occurs 2 days after arrival at altitude. Presentation is dyspnea at rest, a dry cough, rales, tachypnea and tachycardia. The treatment is oxygen and descent to increase the partial pressure of oxygen. If there is a change in the level of consciousness or development of seizures then HACE must be ruled out. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th edition (2018), p. 1793

stem: When evaluating a landing zone during a scene response, the HIGHEST priority for the flight crew is:
rationale: Safety is the flight crew's chief priority. When evaluating a potential landing zone, identifying obstructions is one of the steps to ensure the scene is safe. Ensuring ground personnel contact, communicating with dispatch, and monitoring wind direction are each important but not the highest priority in evaluating the landing zone from the air. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 108

stem: A flight team is dispatched to transport a patient with circumferential full-thickness burns to the chest. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator. The flight nurse notes the peak inspiratory pressure to be 45 cm H2O. Which of the following is the BEST intervention for this finding?
options: B) Perform escharotomies to the thorax
D) Switch the mode to pressure control
rationale: Due to the loss of elasticity of the tissue following a burn, it may become difficult to ventilate a patient. Performing escharotomies will enable effective ventilation. Although suctioning the patient may help with oxygenation, it will not change the lung compliance. As this is a burn patient with bilateral breath sounds, a tube thoracostomy is not indicated at this point. Changing the mode to pressure control will not change the decreased lung compliance caused by the circumferential burns to the chest. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 282

stem: The flight crew is transporting an infant who was delivered at 34 weeks and presents with increasing lethargy and cool skin. The PRIORITY laboratory assessment should be
rationale: Preterm newborns are prone to hypoglycemia due to impaired glycogen storage. This child may not have enough glycogen stored to maintain a normal blood glucose level, as most glycogen storage occurs during the third trimester. Lactate, sodium, and PaCO2 are not the priority labs used to identify the immediate life threat. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 4/73

stem: The transport team has been called to a Labor and Delivery unit to transport a 32-week pregnant patient with gestational diabetes, Group B strep, and influenza to a tertiary facility. While receiving report, which of the following findings would lead the transport nurse to suspect that labor is imminent?
options: A) Moderate fetal heart rate variability
rationale: Cervical dilation exceeding 4 cm indicates impending labor, regardless of previous pregnancies. A -3 fetal station indicates the presenting part is situated 3 cm above the ischial spines and has not yet entered the true pelvis. A cervical effacement of 20% is considered mild and usually does not indicate significant progression toward labor. Normal moderate variability in fetal heart rate is expected and does not imply that labor is imminent. The flight nurse can expect preterm infants to deliver at less than 10 cm dilation. Reference: Advanced Critical Care for the Transport Professional, 1st Ed. (2024), p. 155.

stem: The flight nurse has responded to a patient who was trapped in a burning house. On initial assessment, singed facial hair, erythema of the oropharynx and carbonaceous sputum is noted. Which pathophysiologic change should be INITIALLY anticipated when managing the ventilation of this patient?
rationale: Noxious chemicals from combustion adhere to the surface of the smoke particles and cause direct damage to the airway epithelium, especially in the smaller airways and terminal bronchi which impairs oxygen exchange. Inhalation injuries do not usually cause spontaneous pneumothorax although aggressive positive pressure ventilation could cause a pneumothorax. Pneumonia would be a more delayed concern. Inhalation injuries cause hypoxia versus hypercarbia. Reference: Transport Professional Advanced Trauma Course, 6th Ed. (2018), p. 107

stem: After arriving on scene of a rollover accident on the highway involving a tractor-trailer marked with hazardous materials placards, the Incident Commander directs the flight team to:
options: A) Don Level D personal protective equipment and begin treatment in the warm zone
B) Initiate universal personal protective equipment (PPE) and begin treatment in the cold zone
C) Stage in the landing zone, pending identification of the hazardous materials
D) Don Level A personal protective equipment and begin triage in the warm zone
rationale: Patients in the cold zone have already been decontaminated, thus universal PPE is appropriate. The warm zone is where decontamination takes place; as such, the flight suit, which is a form of Level D PPE, is not adequate protection. Level A PPE is the highest level protection with a fully encapsulated suit and self-contained air supply; these are reserved for the highest trained hazardous materials technicians. Identifying the hazardous materials is important, but treatment can begin as soon as decontamination takes place. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 71-72

stem: The flight crew is flying over water when the pilot informs the team that there is an in-flight emergency, and his intention is to 'ditch the helicopter.' The flight nurse knows it is important to:
options: A) Release the seatbelt prior to impact
B) Kick feet during to clear doors
C) Allow the helicopter to completely invert before trying to exit
D) Exit the helicopter immediately after impact
rationale: During a water landing in a helicopter, it is important to wait for the craft to fully invert and all but fill with water prior to attempting egress. Trying to exit prior to this can lead to the helicopter capsizing on top of you or getting obstructed by the blades and debris. Kicking is to be avoided during egress as you could inadvertently become tangled or injure a coworker. You should not release your seat belt prior to impact to avoid being ejected or thrown about the cabin. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 144

stem: The nurse is transporting a 78-year-old patient from a community ED to a tertiary hospital for altered mental status. Prolonged QT segments are observed on the monitor. The head CT was negative and the toxicology screen was also negative. Medication history includes Trandate (Labetalol), Lasix (Furosemide), and Aspirin. The blood chemistries are included on the transfer form: Glucose: 149 mg/dL Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL PCO2: 29 mmHg Chloride: 105 mEq/L Sodium: 136 mEq/L Potassium: 2.0 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 30 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL The correct action for the nurse is to:
options: A) Initiate a potassium IV infusion
B) Administer a Calcium Gluconate bolus
D) Initiate a dextrose IV infusion
rationale: The elderly patient usually is on many medications and may take them incorrectly. This patient took too much Lasix causing a dangerous drop in Potassium. The patient can have fatal arrhythmias due to QT prolongation and is not the priority. Calcium is within the normal range, therefore calcium gluconate is not the priority. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 5/78

stem: What term describes stress that is considered normal, encountered in daily living, and may enhance function, heighten awareness, or provide new perspectives?
rationale: Eustress is a type of stress that is nonthreatening and generally makes humans perform better. Distress involves noxious stimuli. Somatization and cognitive are not types of stress. Reference: AACN Core Curriculum for High Acuity, Progressive, and Critical Care Nursing (2016), p. 703

stem: During resuscitation of a polytrauma patient, the flight nurse knows what lab value is indicative of impaired perfusion and increased mortality rate.
rationale: Elevated lactate (greater than 4 mmol/L) is indicative of increased anaerobic metabolism and indicative of oxygen deficit within the tissues, which shows a decrease in perfusion. Potassium and sodium are not indicative of poor perfusion. Base excess of -2 is within a normal range. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 208

stem: While transporting a pregnant patient in preterm labor, the transport nurse notes fetal bradycardia and finds a prolapsed umbilical cord. Initial intervention should include
options: A) manual displacement of the presenting part
C) attempted replacement of the umbilical cord
rationale: Elevation of the presenting part with a hand in the vagina is done to prevent further cord compression. Positioning in Trendelenburg or the knee-chest position can also be attempted. Supine maternal positioning will not help and may additionally cause maternal hypotension due to supine hypotension syndrome. Attempted replacement of the umbilical cord would be dangerous. Although the cord may spontaneously retract, the cord should never be manually replaced because severe compression may occur. Tocolysis is indicated to slow contractions and reduce the pressure on the cord. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 449

stem: When administering medications to the geriatric patient population, the flight nurse understands that:
options: A) The patient has less fat reserves, so larger doses should be administered
B) The patient is less sensitive to medications, so larger doses should be administered
C) The patient's liver function is lower, so lower doses should be administered
D) The patient has not increased kidney function, so smaller doses should be administered
rationale: The older adult generally has lower function of end organs and increased fat reserves. Medications should be given carefully as they will not be metabolized as quickly as in the younger adult population. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 1005

stem: On arrival to the scene of a high-speed MVC, the flight crew receives a patient lying in the ambulance that is pregnant at 32-weeks gestation. The patient is awake and alert, complaining of sharp suprapubic pain. The patient reports a maternal history of G2, P1 and received prenatal care. The patient has a previous history of a c-section. Assessment reveals asymmetrical uterus and rebound tenderness. Based on this assessment, the nurse is concerned for which of the following conditions?
rationale: Classic signs of uterine rupture are an asymmetric uterus, suprapubic pain, and palpable fetal parts. Ovarian lacerations typically present with signs and symptoms of retroperitoneal bleeding. Classic signs and symptoms of abruptio placenta are dark red vaginal bleeding, a board-like uterus, and a rising fundal height. Preterm labor does not fit this clinical picture. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 9th ed. (2024), p. 336.

stem: The flight nurse is called to a community hospital for a neonate in distress. The newborn is cyanotic and has an oxygen saturation of 60% on room air which worsened with high-flow oxygen. Prior to transport, the nurse should request administration of:
rationale: This infant is likely suffering from a transposition of the great arteries. The ductus arteriosus needs to be kept open until surgical correction can be performed. Prostaglandins should be administered cautiously, as it can cause apnea. These patients usually require intubation. The other medications would not be indicated in this case. Reference: Nelson's Essentials of Pediatrics, p. 569.

stem: The transport team is on scene of a chemical release at a manufacturing plant. The team notices numerous patients walking towards them vomiting and exhibiting urinary and fecal incontinence. The team should:
options: A) Identify the source of the contaminant
B) Don level A personal protective equipment
C) Properly administer Atropine to the patients
D) Stage in the cold zone
rationale: The patients are exhibiting signs and symptoms of exposure to organophosphate pesticides or nerve agent chemicals, thus they need to be decontaminated prior to treatment. Atropine is used as an antidote to organophosphates and nerve agents, the transport team cannot begin treating patients until they are decontaminated. Identifying the source of the contaminant is necessary, but is a lower priority than protecting the transport team's safety. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 47-49

stem: Following an emergency landing, a critical incident stress debriefing is held. Two months later, a flight nurse who was involved in the incident seems uninterested in work, startles easily, and complains of frequent flashbacks and nightmares. Which of the following should the manager do?
options: A) Arrange for the nurse to receive individual counseling
B) Evaluate the nurse for substance abuse
C) Remove the nurse from duty immediately
D) Advise this is a normal stress response for the nurse
rationale: This is not normal stress because it is interfering with daily living. Removing the nurse from duty and having the nurse tested for substance abuse would be punitive in nature and should be avoided. Arranging for individual counseling for the nurse to work through the issue with a professional counselor fits with current practices of CISM. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 802

stem: During transport, a patient suffers cardiopulmonary arrest. The flight nurse proceeds with intubation to secure an airway. Which method of assessment for determining proper ETT placement is BEST in this situation?
options: B) Proper ETCO2 waveform on monitor
C) Absence of air movement in stomach
D) Auscultation of bilateral lung sounds
rationale: Proper ETCO2 waveform is the best method of assessment. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 1/6

stem: The flight nurse enters an ambulance and finds several paramedics and police officers attempting to restrain a combative patient who is actively bleeding from a self-inflicted wrist laceration. The patient is resisting care and is stating 'let me die! I want to die!' Which type of consent allows the flight nurse to treat the patient?
rationale: A patient who is suicidal and in police custody or under a physician's emergency commitment can not refuse life-saving treatments. This self-inflicted wound may be fatal without immediate treatment. Patients that are suicidal, homicidal, delusional, or experiencing other psychiatric emergencies may not be able to think rationally and the flight nurse can legally treat the patient, even if resisting care, when acting in good faith. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 7

stem: A patient with atrial fibrillation complains of a sudden onset of pain and numbness in the right forearm. The arm is cool to the touch and has a thready radial pulse. The transport nurse should suspect which of the following?
rationale: The nurse should suspect arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis is a common complication of atrial fibrillation. An embolus which mobilizes into the upper extremities would manifest itself with these findings. Venous insufficiency is most commonly associated with the lower extremities and is a chronic condition. Classic findings include venous ulcers, skin discoloration, and enlarged or varicose veins. Compartment syndrome is an acute finding, generally associated with trauma. Long bone fractures are present in as much as 20% of all patients presenting with compartment syndrome. Other causes such as drug abuse, anticoagulant use, and other chronic medical conditions have also been associated with compartment syndrome. Myocardial ischemia is commonly manifested with pain radiating to the left arm and neck, and does not usually cause vascular changes to the upper extremities. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 303

stem: A transport nurse observes blood in the catheter connection tubing of a patient receiving intra-aortic balloon (IABP) therapy. The nurse should FIRST
options: A) manually flush the arterial line
B) disconnect and manually inflate the balloon
C) clamp the connection tubing to the balloon catheter
rationale: The presence of blood in the catheter connection tubing is the hallmark of balloon rupture. It requires immediate cessation of pumping and removal of the IABP. Continued use of a ruptured balloon can lead to helium gas embolization, a potentially fatal event. The balloon is most likely ruptured. Although intact balloons that are not actively pumping should be intermittently, manually inflated according to the manufacturer's directions to prevent clot formation, manual inflation of a ruptured balloon will inject gas into the aorta through the defect in the balloon. Flushing and re-zeroing of the arterial line are appropriate only if the balloon is intact. These measures will not clear blood in the catheter tubing. Although the desired action in the presence of balloon rupture is to prevent gas pumping into the balloon, the correct course of action is to cease pumping, not merely clamp the connection tubing. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 331

stem: A flight team is transporting a patient by fixed-wing aircraft at a cruising altitude of 40,000 feet. The flight nurse observes a fog-like mist within the interior of the cabin. The nurse's FIRST action should be to
options: A) administer oxygen to the patient
B) ensure that all passengers and equipment are secured
D) check outlets and medical equipment for smoke
rationale: The nurse should first begin breathing supplemental oxygen. Mist or 'fog' within the aircraft's cabin at altitude most likely indicates decompression. The nurse should first ensure that he or she is protected from hypoxia as a result of exposure to reduced barometric pressure. Administering oxygen to the patient is a secondary action. Time of useful consciousness at 40,000 feet is 15 seconds or less. If the nurse is disabled by hypoxia, then further helpful actions would not be possible. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 40

stem: In a helicopter safety and landing zone (LZ) presentation to a local EMS service, which of the following is the MOST important instruction for EMS personnel?
options: A) Approach only from the loading side of the helicopter
B) Utilize ambulance lights to highlight the LZ
C) Ensure LZ is at least 200' x 200'
D) Proceed toward the aircraft only when directed by the pilot
rationale: The scene call environment is one of the most potentially hazardous aspects of air medical operations. Safety is of paramount importance and situational awareness must be maintained when working around an aircraft. Ground personnel should only be allowed to approach the aircraft when directed to do so by the pilot or a flight crew member. The pilot in command of the aircraft must be able to see personnel approaching. Mitigating the hazard from air medical operations on ground personnel is the most important instruction. The LZ can be a minimum of 75' x 75' during the day and 125' x 125' at night. While some situations may require lighting the landing zone, the MOST important instruction for EMS personnel should be to approach only when directed. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 142

stem: Which of the following cranial nerves is responsible for pupillary response in a closed head injury patient?
rationale: Oculomotor is correct. Oculomotor (CN III) is responsible for pupillary response. Optic Nerve (CN II) is visual acuity, visual fields, reading printed material, and seeing light. Trigeminal is responsible for corneal reflex and facial sensation. Abducens (CN VI) is responsible for extraocular eye movement. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 634

stem: The flight team is called to transport a 6-month-old child diagnosed with febrile seizures. Upon arrival, hospital staff states the child has lost IV access and two additional attempts have been made to initiate access, which have been unsuccessful. Vital signs: BP 68/40 mmHg HR 178 beats/min RR 36 breaths/min T(rectal) 103°F (39.4C) O2 Sat 99% (room air) The NEXT appropriate stop is:
options: C) Attempt a third intravenous access
rationale: This child is presenting with shock, elevated HR and low BP. It is pertinent to obtain access on this child to initiate fluid resuscitation. Intraosseous access can be obtained quickly, and fluid resuscitation can be started without further delay. The other three options would delay fluid administration and therefore could be harmful to the patient outcome. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 2/15

stem: The flight nurse is called to an accident scene where a patient has been trapped under a fallen tree for several hours and has a crushed leg. IV access has been established. As the patient is extracted, the nurse should prepare to administer
rationale: Crush injuries can cause a large release of potassium. Calcium gluconate is used to neutralize the effects of hyperkalemia. Fentanyl can be given after or before for pain control but is not the priority. Normal saline can be given for volume replacement but is again not the priority. Magnesium chloride would not be a correct choice for this patient. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 199

stem: During a rotor scene call for a 4-year-old patient, the patient's mother requests to ride along with the patient to the hospital. Which of the following statements by the mother would MOST concern the flight crew?
options: A) I would like to speak to the pilot about safety of the flight
B) I get motion sickness easily
C) If I can't hold my child, they won't go with you
D) My child has typical medications/treatments 24-hour base
rationale: The decision to transport a family member is based on multiple factors, and while all of the choices may weigh in the decision, safety of the entire team must be the primary factor. Family members should be instructed that safety regulations require all passengers to wear approved restraint devices (Commercial Flight Rule 135.128). Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 340

stem: The flight crew is called to transport a 6-year-old child who was hit in the chest with a baseball. The patient has had a chest x-ray that shows no fractures to the sternum or ribs. The flight nurse is MOST concerned about which of the following vital signs?
rationale: Children have flexible ribs that are not fully formed, and therefore may not fracture with blunt injuries. Blunt cardiac injuries cannot be ruled out in a pediatric patient with known chest trauma. Cardiac arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation) are likely in the patient with blunt chest trauma. Because the pediatric patient cannot compensate with stroke volume changes, a decreased blood pressure is a concerning sign following thoracic trauma. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 687; Wong's Nursing Care of Infants and Children, 12th Ed. (2024), p. 749

stem: A school-age patient presents after a house fire with 3rd degree circumferential burns of the neck and chest. Physical exam reveals the extent of the burn is 60% total body surface area. The patient also presents with stridor and drooling. Vital signs are: BP: 90/45 mmHg HR: 133 beats/min RR: 28 breaths/min O2 Sat: 100% (room air) GCS: 14 The flight nurse understands that the PRIORITY intervention is:
options: C) Application of dry sterile dressings
rationale: The patient is demonstrating signs and symptoms of smoke inhalation and younger patients are at greater risk for airway obstruction. Oxygen saturation may be inaccurate due to carbon monoxide exposure from an enclosed area. The priority intervention is to protect the airway and initiate early intubation. IV fluids, dressings, and wound debridement are all indicated for burn resuscitation, but they are not the priority. Reference: Advanced Trauma Life Support Student Course Manual, 10th Ed. (2018), p. 171

stem: The nurse is transporting a patient who has suffered an epidural hematoma. What is the BEST indication of a change in intracranial pressure?
rationale: When assessing the patient with a neurologic injury, level of consciousness is the best indication of changes in ICP. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 253

stem: The flight team responds to a facility for a high risk OB transport of a mother with gestational diabetes. The baby has just been delivered and is born limp. A heel stick reveals a blood glucose of 25 mg/dL and an umbilical line has been placed by the delivery team. Appropriate treatment is to administer:
rationale: Critically ill hypoglycemic neonates require IV glucose infusions of 4-6 mg/kg/min of D10W. The other doses and concentrations are not appropriate for this age group. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 4/74

stem: A patient is being transported by air for direct admission to a medical intensive care unit after ingesting a large quantity of ethylene glycol. After verifying the position of the patient's endotracheal tube and that he is breathing spontaneously, the nurse notes that the ETCO2 is 15 mm Hg. The nurse should anticipate the patient will need emergency
rationale: The nurse should anticipate hemodialysis. Ingestion of more than 1 mL/kg of ethylene glycol can often be fatal. Metabolism of ethylene glycol deposit in the kidney, causing renal failure. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 424

stem: The flight crew is called to the scene of a collision where heavy front end damage to the vehicle has caused the vehicle to catch fire. A back seat passenger reports they were able to self extricate after 10 minutes and reports no physical burns. Upon assessment, the nurse notes the patient has soot to their face, and a dry voice. The MOST appropriate next action is:
options: A) Monitor for airway compromise from inhalation burns
B) Administer IV fluid at 100 ml/hr
C) Triage the patient to the basic life support (BLS) ambulance
D) Transport the patient to the closest facility
rationale: Soot on the face and raspy voice are indicative of heavy inhalation burns. This patient should be closely monitored for airway compromise and transported to the nearest burns center. IV fluids important, but not the most important intervention. A BLS ambulance is not recommended due to the potential for airway compromise. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 281

stem: The flight nurse is preparing to transport a patient who was injured and has significant swelling and paresthesia to the left upper extremity. Which order by the sending facility should be questioned?
options: B) Elevate the extremity above the heart
rationale: An extremity with compartment syndrome has reduced blood flow and elevation could further decrease circulation. Immobilization and splinting are appropriate, but caution should be taken not to apply excessive pressure that might impair blood flow. Regular reassessment is necessary to detect any worsening of the condition. The patient may also need analgesics for pain management. Reference: Prehospital Trauma Life Support 10th ed., p. 419

stem: A patient was a restrained driver in a side-impact motor vehicle accident. On assessment, the patient is awake and verbalizing difficulty breathing. The patient appears pale and diaphoretic, tachypneic, and has decreased breath sounds over left lung field. Bony crepitus is palpated over the left chest. Vital signs are as follows: BP 78/56 mm Hg HR 132 beats/min O2 sat 84% The flight nurse should suspect the patient may be experiencing:
rationale: Blunt trauma can cause massive hemothorax as a result of rapid accumulation of >1500 ml of blood in the chest cavity. Rapid accumulation of blood results in severe hypotension and hypoxia. The information from the assessment does not provide mechanism of injury for a cardiac tamponade or assessment findings, such as muffled heart tones. Cardiac tamponade patients are not usually hypoxic. The patient could have a pneumothorax but simple pneumothorax patients are not usually pale and hypotensive. The assessment does not demonstrate a floating segment or inward movement of the chest wall during inspiration and outward movement during expiration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 252

stem: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate intervention to prevent and protect the patient with and to reduce the risk for pulmonary barotrauma from mechanical ventilation?
options: B) Attempt to lower the plateau pressure
C) Increase the fraction of inspired oxygen
rationale: Attempting to lower the plateau pressure is the most appropriate intervention. Maintaining a plateau pressure less than or equal to 35 cm H2O is desired. The other interventions are not the most appropriate interventions. Initiating permissive hypocapnia strategies would mean increasing the tidal volume or the respiratory rate. Both actions may further the barotrauma. Decreasing expiration time is not appropriate, because decreasing the inspiration time will increase the peak inspiratory pressure. Increasing the fraction of inspired oxygen will have no effect on barotrauma. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 191

stem: The flight crew is called to the scene of a patient whose right lower extremity is still entrapped by a trash compactor. The flight crew should be aware of which of the following metabolic changes when the extremity is released?
rationale: Crush syndrome is a serious condition that can threaten both life and limbs following crush injuries. It is characterized by reperfusion injury, which occurs when the trapped limb is released, causing myoglobin and potassium to enter the bloodstream. This causes traumatic rhabdomyolysis, damaging the kidneys and increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. Patients with crush syndrome also develop hypocalcemia because calcium is absorbed by injured muscle cells. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 304

stem: A pediatric near-drowning victim is unresponsive and cyanotic with a pulse of 60 beats/min. The patient is being ventilated via an ET tube. The flight nurse's FIRST action is to
options: A) manually override the pop-off valve
B) add positive end-expiratory pressure to the resuscitator bag
C) administer 1 mg of atropine via the endotracheal tube
rationale: The flight nurse's first action is to assess ET tube placement. Administering 1 mg of atropine is incorrect because bradycardia is hypoxia related. Adding PEEP to the resuscitator bag or manually overriding the pop-off valve will not improve the heart rate if the tube is not in the correct location. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 5/18

stem: The flight team is transporting a patient on dialysis who has an infected arteriovenous shunt. The patient requires rapid sequence intubation en route. The flight nurse knows which of the following medications is contraindicated as an induction agent?
rationale: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing medication. It can cause an increase in potassium. The patient is already likely to have an increased potassium level due to having kidney failure. The other medications would not cause this increase in potassium. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 179

stem: The flight crew is called to transport a patient with aortic dissection. Current vital signs are: HR 52 beats/min BP 135/70 mmHg RR 18 breaths/min SpO2 100% (2L nasal cannula) The MOST appropriate medication to initiate for this patient is:
rationale: The most important management for patients with aortic injury is blood pressure management, with a goal of 90-120mmHg. Nicardipine will decrease blood pressure without affecting heart rate. Esmolol is contraindicated for this patient due to low heart rate. Epinephrine will increase blood pressure. Fentanyl is important for pain control, but will not affect blood pressure effectively for this patient. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), pp. 247

stem: A patient with a saddle pulmonary embolism has become more lethargic. The patient's vital signs are: BP 72/47 mm Hg HR 120 beats/min RR 28 breaths/min O2 Sat 80% (room air) The NEXT appropriate intervention should be to administer which of the following?
rationale: Alteplase (Activase) is correct because it will actively dissolve a clot. The other medications do not dissolve existing clots. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 10th edition (2018), p. 1063

stem: Which of the following medications is BEST for treating an increase in heart rate and blood pressure in a chemically paralyzed patient?
rationale: Although the patient received a neuromuscular blocker (NMB) or paralytic, the NMB will not alter the patient's level of consciousness. Sedation must accompany the NMB or the patient will be chemically paralyzed with the potential of being fully awake. Administration of a short-acting paralytic drug is not appropriate. The change in vital signs is not related to neuromuscular blockade, but is likely due to awareness, beta blockade will manage the symptoms, but not the cause of the tachycardia and hypertension. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 128

stem: The flight crew is transporting a 140kg patient from the scene of a motor vehicle collision that sustained blunt abdominal trauma. Bruising is noted to the left flank. Vital signs include: BP: 78/54 mmHg HR: 162 beats/min RR: 28 breaths/min SpO2: 92% (15L nonrebreating mask) On arrival to the facility, the nurse knows that which diagnostic test will be MOST beneficial?
options: A) Kidney, ureter, and bladder (KUB) x-ray
