stem: A nurse is transporting a patient with a 12-lead ECG showing 3 mm ST elevation in leads V1-V6, I, aVL, with ST depression in leads II, III, aVF. These ECG changes indicate what type of myocardial infarction?
rationale: The V1-V6 leads face the anterior wall and indicate left anterior descending artery stenosis. An anterior MI shows ST elevation in V1-V4; inferior MI shows elevation in II, III, aVF; lateral MI shows elevation in I, aVL, V5, V6. Reference: AACN Essentials of Critical Care Nursing, 3rd Ed. (2014), p. 446

stem: The flight crew arrives at a facility to transport a patient involved in a high-velocity T-bone collision. The patient was intubated for respiratory distress, and a chest tube was placed at the fifth intercostal space, midaxillary line. The nurse notes fecal matter in the drainage system. What does the flight nurse suspect to be the cause?
rationale: This patient shows signs of a diaphragmatic hernia caused by a high-velocity impact. The chest tube is likely correctly positioned, but the patient's bowel is in the chest cavity where the chest tube is located. Diaphragmatic perforation is associated with bile or stomach contents in the chest tube drainage. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 157

stem: The flight crew is called to transport a patient with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). Flight time via rotor wing is approximately 1 hour. What is the most important consideration for flight planning for this patient?
options: A) Ensure there is adequate power supply to plug the IABP during transport
B) Maintain head of the bed elevation of 30 degrees
C) Maintain non-invasive blood pressure monitoring during the entire transport
D) Ensure compatibility of the transport IABP and referring facility IABP pressure lines
rationale: With prolonged transport time, it is imperative to ensure there is an adequate power source for the IABP during transport. Pressure lines can be switched to accommodate the flight team's equipment. 30 degrees head of the bed elevation is contraindicated for patients with IABP therapy. Non-invasive blood pressures are not routinely monitored in patients with IABP because the IABP displays augmented pressures. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 330

stem: When considering the serious hazards to first responders, the most MOST dangerous time to approach the helicopter on scene is:
rationale: At lower speeds, for example during startup or shut down, gusts of wind can cause the blades to flap or sail. This may allow the blades to stop below shoulder level and can cause serious injury or death. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 104

stem: A helicopter is landing at an accident scene. The pilot has conducted both high and low reconnaissance flights. While on the final approach, the flight nurse notices wires in the flight path at the two o'clock position. How should the flight nurse report this finding?
options: A) Ask the partner "Are there wires at two o'clock?"
C) Request an alternate landing zone
D) State "I think I see wires."
rationale: Aviation-related hazards should be identified by their clock location and described in clear, unambiguous language. A corrective action should be provided to clarify the nature of the threat. Reference: https://www.usheli.org/Press_Releases/ACTS%20crew%20resource%20management%20A.pdf, p. 3

stem: The flight crew is called for an interfacility transfer of a 3-year-old patient involved in a high-speed MVA with partial ejection. The patient was reported to have a declining mental status on arrival to the ED and required intubation. Radiographs and CT scans were negative for head or spinal injuries. During transport, the flight crew knows that a PRIORITY intervention is to:
options: B) Provide for family presence during transport
rationale: Pediatric patients are at risk for spinal cord injuries without radiological abnormalities (SCIWORA). Despite negative imaging, spinal motion restrictions are indicated for pediatric patients with high-risk MVA. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th edition (2024), p. 189

stem: The flight crew has arrived on scene to a mass shooting. Police on scene state that the shooter is not yet in custody. The PRIORITY the team should make before rendering aid to the injured is:
options: B) Location of the cold zone
D) Time to nearest trauma center
rationale: The safety of the flight team is the top priority for any disaster. The cold zone is a safe, secured area in which the patient should be assessed and can be safely transported away to a healthcare facility. The flight team cannot render aid if they are not safe. The other items are important, but not the most important. Rescuers should never be compromised in order to render aid. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 72, 86

stem: The nurse is transporting a patient on a fixed wing aircraft at 40,000 feet. They notice a fog developing in the cabin. Their FIRST action should be to:
options: A) Check the aircraft door seal
B) Use emergency oxygen for themselves
D) Check the oxygen valve for leaks
rationale: The fog in the cabin is a probable sign of aircraft decompression. This decompression can cause loss of conscious in seconds. The nurse should apply oxygen to themselves before attempting to help their patient or attempting to notify the pilot. The nurse can then troubleshoot the cause of the leak with the pilot. The pilot should descend rapidly to under 10,000 feet. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 40

stem: The nurse is called to transport a 2-year-old who has been sick for three days. The patient's mother states the child has had decreasing PO intake, and the mother states the child is not acting normally. A concerning assessment finding noted by the flight nurse is:
options: A) The child wants to be held by its mother
B) The patient cries when moved to the transport stretcher
C) The patient's respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min
D) The child is cooperative for IV placement
rationale: A child who does not react to the environment around them should be considered an abnormal behavior and indicate that the child is ill. The other behaviors are normal for a child who is ill. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 524

stem: The flight crew has just completed the transport of a patient with HIV infection and bloody diarrhea. Decontamination of the transport vehicle should be accomplished by:
options: B) Use of a specifically labeled sporicidal
D) Airing out the vehicle prior to decontamination
rationale: Clostridium difficile is common in patients with HIV that have diarrhea. Decontamination can be difficult, as the spores can survive on surfaces for months and are resistant to most cleaning solutions that are not specifically labeled as sporicidal. Airing out the vehicle is indicated in airborne infectious diseases (i.e. SARS, MERS, COVID). Alcohol may be effective against C. difficile bacterium, but not against the spores. Soap and water is useful in removing spores during handwashing, but not from equipment. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 394

stem: A transport nurse should determine that a patient with chlorine gas exposure is appropriately treated when:
options: D) The skin pH is greater than 7.35
rationale: At high exposure levels, initiation of the upper respiratory tract and accumulation of fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) contributes to wheezing, cough, and dyspnea. Acute lung injury and/or ARDS can result in severe cases. Because this gas is primarily reactive only at a local level, absorbed systemic effects are not commonly observed. Skin pH measures are not a good measure of skin decontamination. Hyperventilation is a cholinergic syndrome and is not associated with chlorine gas exposure. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th Edition (2018), p. 732-733

stem: A nurse is preparing to transport a patient who has received a massive transfusion. Which of the following BEST indicates abdominal compartment syndrome?
rationale: Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by abdominal hypertension and the subsequent organ dysfunction it causes, such as decreased urinary output (oliguria). Hematochezia is not an indicator of abdominal compartment syndrome. Hypoperfusion caused by increased intra-abdominal hypertension results in metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis. Increasing intra-abdominal pressure will cause a decrease in pulmonary compliance, resulting in increased plateau pressures. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 372

stem: The nurse is transporting a patient who has encephalopathy and a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient is orally intubated, jaundiced, has ascites and an indwelling urinary catheter draining dark amber urine. The transport nurse should:
options: A) Evaluate the INR before gastric tube placement
B) Avoid administration of dextrose-containing fluids
C) Request an abdominal CT scan prior to transport
rationale: Nasogastric tube placement may be contraindicated in certain patient populations. Patients who are coagulopathic, or have facial trauma and subsequent instability, require careful consideration prior to placement of a nasogastric tube. Requesting an abdominal CT would cause a delay in transport and would yield limited diagnostic information. Administering dextrose is indicated in this case. Administering naloxone (Narcan) is not indicated as there is no information that would suggest this is an opioid overdose. Reference: AACN Procedure Manual for High Acuity, Progressive and Critical Care, 7th Ed. (2017), p. 1221

stem: What information would lead the transport team to suspect a biological agent exposure?
options: A) Appearance of a disease during its peak season
B) Clusters of patients in the same location with the same symptoms
C) Multiple outbreaks of some illness with different onset times
D) Multiple patients with dissimilar complaints
rationale: Initially small clusters of patients in a similar geographical area, experiencing similar characteristics/symptoms, should cause agencies to suspect biological agent exposure as the source patient comes into contact with other individuals and the infection spreads. It is essential to identify this phase early on, before spread occurs at longer distances from the source patient location. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 623-627

stem: The nurse arrives at a rural hospital to transport a patient who has been involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient is awake, and complains of abdominal pain and left shoulder pain. Vital signs are: BP: 85/48 mmHg HR: 118 beats/min RR: 26 breaths/min O2 Sat: 100% (15L non-rebreather mask) Pain: 8/10 Initial assessment of this patient should begin with:
rationale: The patient is presenting with Kehr's sign, which is indicative of splenic injury and blood in the peritoneal cavity. They are hypotensive and tachycardic. Initial resuscitation should begin with blood administration, followed by platelets, plasma, and cryoprecipitate if available. While the pain may need to be addressed, replacing lost blood products takes priority. TXA should be initiated after blood product resuscitation. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 205

stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient diagnosed with a new onset seizure disorder. What is the MOST important intervention during the start-up and shutdown of the aircraft to prevent triggering repeated seizure-like activity?
options: A) Applying oxygen via face mask
B) Administering ondansetron 20 mg to prevent nausea
C) Place ear protection on the patient
D) Using a hat to shield the patient's eyes
rationale: Flicker vertigo can occur when transport team members and patients are exposed to lights that flicker at a rate of 4 to 20 cycles per second. It can cause nausea and vomiting; in severe cases, it can cause seizures and unconsciousness. Flicker vertigo commonly occurs when sunlight flickers through the rotor blades of a helicopter or an airplane propeller. It has also been triggered by light from rotating beacons against an overcast sky. Transport team members or patients with a history of seizures are at risk for flicker vertigo. Wearing a hat with a bill and sunglasses can prevent flicker vertigo. Adequate rest and stress management may also decrease the risk. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 8th Ed. (2024), p. 56

stem: The flight team has been requested to transfer a patient diagnosed with syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone. The flight nurse knows that frequent neuro checks are required, as cerebral edema can result from:
rationale: Cytotoxic edema is an increase in fluid in the neurons, glia, and endothelial cells as a result of sodium-potassium pump failure so that fluid and sodium accumulate within the cell. This can be seen with syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). The other forms of edema are not complications of SIADH. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 288

stem: The flight nurse is assessing a patient with abdominal trauma and notes bleeding from the gums and IV site. Before transport, the nurse should ask for:
rationale: The patient is experiencing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The nurse should replace the clotting factors with FFP. PRBCs are important for trauma but will not reverse DIC. While Kogenate and vitamin K might be indicated for some trauma patients, it is not the priority intervention. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 293

stem: The flight nurse is transfusing one unit of whole blood to a mechanically ventilated patient during transport. During the transfusion, the nurse notes that the patient's plateau pressure has increased to 35 cmH2O, their systolic blood pressure has dropped 30 mmHg, and their temperature has increased by 2° Celsius. The patient's neck veins are flat. In addition to stopping the transfusion, the flight nurse knows that the NEXT best treatment is:
options: B) Administer a 500 mL isotonic fluid bolus
rationale: The above symptoms are strongly suggestive of transfusion related acute lung injury (TRALI). TRALI is an increase in fluid supportive and inclusive, and increased PEEP helps to improve oxygenation. The other choices do not improve oxygenation. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing, 9th Edition (2019), p. 116

stem: A patient is being transported post-cardiac catheterization by rotor-wing. There is a transradial compression band in place. During the ascent phase of the flight, the patient complains of increasing pain at the access site. The flight crew recognizes this complication may be due to:
options: A) Complete hemostasis of the radial artery
B) Increasing volume in the transradial band
rationale: Boyle's law states that at a constant temperature, the volume of gas is inversely proportional to its pressure. The gas in a balloon, such as the TR Band, expands during ascent. This occurs because there is less pressure as the balloon ascends higher into the atmospheric air; the balloon expands because of decreased pressure. The effects of this law can be seen in several clinical situations. As an unpressurized aircraft ascends, patients can exhibit pneumothorax expansion, rupture of air-endotracheal tube cuffs, and gastric distension. If gas expansion is a concern, consider requesting the pilot to fly at the lowest, safest altitude. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 8th Ed. (2024), p. 52

stem: Mechanical noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) is MOST successful in patients with:
rationale: The strongest evidence of support for the successful use of NPPV is in patients with acute exacerbation of COPD and acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. NPPV is contraindicated in patients with hemodynamic instability, upper airway obstruction, unstable arrhythmias, and cardiac or respiratory arrest. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 242

stem: A patient who has an Impella device is being transported. The flight nurse should know that the P level should be changed for which situation?
rationale: The P level should only be adjusted during transport for two reasons: CPR and a sudden alarm. Otherwise the P level should not be adjusted. The P level should then be adjusted to P2. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 333

stem: Treatment for acute decompression illness includes which of the following?
options: A) Climb back to an acceptable altitude
C) 250 mg acetazolamide (Diamox) slow IV push
rationale: Rapid descent along with 100% oxygen is the initial treatment for acute decompression illness. 250 mg acetazolamide (Diamox) slow IV push is the treatment for acute mountain sickness. It is not a treatment for acute decompression illness. Climbing back to an acceptable altitude is used for barotrauma or ear block and not acute decompression illness. Positive pressure ventilation would not have any effect on the cause of the decompression illness. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 41

stem: Although primarily a childhood illness, transport crew members can develop varicella after being exposed to:
options: B) Direct contact with the patient's intact skin
C) Direct contact with the patient's feces
rationale: Varicella (Chickenpox) is spread via aerosolized nasopharyngeal droplets and via contact with fluid in the vesicular rash. Varicella is not spread via contact with intact skin, feces, or blood. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 392

stem: A rotor-wing transport team experiences an engine failure and has a forced landing in water. Which of the following is the correct sequence for successful egress from the helicopter?
rationale: Helicopters almost always capsize after settling into the water. A flight nurse should wait until the aircraft has stopped moving before exiting. The first step is to unplug the helmet or headset, unstrop from the seatbelts, exit through the closest exit available, and then inflate the flotation devices. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 117

stem: Patients with which condition may present with acute respiratory muscle insufficiency, diplopia, or dysphagia?
rationale: Diplopia is associated with all of the listed answers. In its chronic form, myasthenia gravis may cause symptoms such as dysphagia, muscle weakness, fatigue, and dysarthria. In myasthenia gravis crisis, patients may present with acute respiratory muscle insufficiency requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 10th Edition (2020), p. 150-162

stem: The goal of intra-aortic balloon pump counter pulsation therapy is to:
options: A) Increase afterload and decrease left ventricular filling pressures
B) Decrease afterload and decrease left ventricular filling pressures
C) Increase afterload and increase left ventricular filling pressures
D) Increase afterload and decrease left ventricular filling pressures
rationale: The balloon inflates during ventricular diastole, increasing intra-aortic pressure and blood flow to the coronary arteries. The balloon deflates just prior to ventricular systole, decreasing intra-aortic pressure. This pressure decrease reduces the resistance to left ventricular ejection, or afterload, and decreases left ventricular filling pressures. Afterload and left ventricle pressures would increase if the intra-aortic balloon pump timing was incorrect and showed late deflation, which then causes an increase in the workload and oxygen consumption of the heart. Reference: AACN Essentials of Critical Care Nursing, 3rd Ed. (2014), p. 497
